attributes.title: An idiographic approach to assess the negative effects of Instagram on mental health

q1.value: An idiographic approach to assess the negative effects of Instagram on mental health

q2.value: Allison Diamond Altman, Aaron J. Fisher

q3.value: Social networking sites have grown extensively over the past decade, coinciding with the growing use of internet-enabled smartphones that allow access to these sites virtually at any moment. One social networking app, Instagram, allows for passive observation of other’s photos, and extant work has indicated negative effects in cross sectional samples, though longitudinal studies have garnered mixed findings. Given the potential negative consequences of social media use on health, it is pertinent for researchers to examine these constructs in more detail and on an individual, or idiographic basis, in order to inform interventions that may ameliorate harmful effects of use. This project proposes to use ecological momentary assessment to investigate the immediate effects of using Instagram on mental health at an idiographic level, as well as look at moderators of these relationships. This work has the significance to clarify a link between Instagram use and negative affect on a person-specific basis, and to reveal certain moderators of this interaction, which will all be key for proposing interventions and informing what responsible phone usage is for teens and adults alike.

q4.value:
1.) In the nomothetic analyses, increased Instagram use will not be significantly associated with increases in three mental health items: affect, jealousy, and social comparison, but that in the idiographic analyses, certain individuals will show increased Instagram use to be significantly associated with increases in three mental health items: affect, jealousy, and social comparison.

2.) Trait social comparison orientation, pre-existing internalizing disorder symptoms, and female sex will each positively moderate the relationships between Instagram use and increase in mental health symptoms.

3.) At the nomothetic level there will be no significant contemporaneous correlation between Instagram use and avoidance but for some individuals there will be strong contemporaneous correlations.

4.) Diagnoses of anxiety disorders (including generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder), and pre-existing symptoms of anxiety as measured by the Penn State Worry Questionnaire will positively moderate the contemporaneous relationship between Instagram use and avoidance.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The proposed project will utilize ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to examine the moment-to-moment relationships among Instagram use, negative affect, social comparison, and jealousy. Aside from our interest in overall affect, jealousy and social comparison were chosen specifically due to past research suggesting these being highly implicated in social media use. I will use both contemporaneous and time-lagged analyses in order to examine how these things are associated at any given point in time, as well as how they drive each other from moment to moment. Subjects (n=300) will initially present to the lab to be administered a short neuropsychiatric interview and to complete demographic and baseline measures of affect and mental health symptoms and key variables of social media usage including number of followers and number of individuals they follow, and the breakdown of whether or not these followers are strangers or known to the individual. After this, subjects will be introduced to the EMA system to collect intensive repeated measures data, whereby phone surveys will be administered sixteen times a day for 1 week, assessing questions about their Instagram use over the proceeding time since the past survey, experiences of affect, jealousy, and social comparison on a 0-100 scale, and items to assess direct social interaction and other media use. 

After first assessing contemporaneous relationships among the variables using correlational analyses, both nomothetic (group-level) and idiographic (person-specific) lagged autoregressive models will be employed to the data. To do this, structural equation models will be fit to the time-series data obtained from EMA. First, we will create time-lagged covariance matrices (known as block-Toeplitz matrices) and average these across individuals to test the model at the nomothetic, group-aggregated level. For the idiographic approach, we will test the same model separately for each individual, fitting the model separately for each participant’s time series (see Figure 1 as a general example). As we have three outcome variables (affect, jealousy, and social comparison), 3 models will be fit for each participant. Afterwards, moderation analyses will be run to see potential moderators of the observed relationships emerge, including diagnoses of distress disorders, age, sex, and socioeconomic status.

Furthermore, we aim to examine to what extent Instagram is used for avoidance by assessing the contemporaneous relationships between Instagram use and avoidance at the nomothetic and idiographic levels, and assess whether group-level psychopathological characteristics of the sample (i.e. psychopathological diagnosis, depression symptoms, and anxiety symptoms) strengthen or moderate the contemporaneous relationship between Instagram use and avoidance. To do this, data from each individual’s time series will be combined into a larger nomothetic dataset. We will run a Pearson correlation between the contemporaneous (Time t) avoidance and contemporaneous (Time t) Instagram use at the nomothetic and at the idiographic level, meaning for each participant. To assess whether theoretically-relevant group-level characteristics of the sample (measured at baseline) moderate the strength of the correlation between avoidance and Instagram use, we will examine whether psychopathological variables (including anxiety disorder diagnosis as measured by the M.I.N.I., and symptoms of anxiety as measured by the PSWQ) interact with the correlation coefficient between avoidance and Instagram use.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
300 young adult subjects (aged 18-35) from the community will be recruited via craigslist ads and postings, as well as through the Research Participation Program (RPP) at the University of California, Berkeley, and after a brief phone screen to determine initial eligibility conducted by a trained research assistant, they will present to the Idiographic Dynamics Lab at UC Berkeley. A trained research assistant will conduct the M.I.N.I, and then participants will be instructed to complete demographic and baseline measures of well-being, affect, psychopathology, and Instagram and Facebook addiction. Key variables of social media usage including number of followers and number of individuals they follow and the breakdown of whether or not these followers are strangers or known to the individual will also be collected.

After this, subjects will be introduced to the EMA system. In order to systematically ensure that participants are responding to prompts consistently, they will be given a list of synonyms and vignettes corresponding to each of the seven constructs that will be assessed during the EMA period. A trained experimenter will review each of the items in detail, asking participants to generate examples of times they have experienced category in their own lives. To ensure correct understanding, participants will be presented with a new set of seven vignettes corresponding to each EMA question category, and will be asked to appropriately categorize them. Their response data will be recorded, and they will be given corrective feedback as to the accuracy as necessary. In the event that participants are not able to correctly respond to the vignettes after multiple attempts, they will be compensated for the lab portion of the study and will not asked to continue participation in the next steps of the study.

Lastly, participants will be given instructions on how to use the EMA system on their smartphones, including instructions and a step-by-step walkthrough of how to correctly download the LifeData application, which will be used to send the EMA prompts. Participants will be asked to complete the assessments when prompted for the following week. Participants will be told that their compensation for participating in the study is contingent upon their completing at least 80% of the assessments. A sampling frequency of 16 times per day will be used, as this is at the faster end of published EMA studies in the emotion literature, and is hypothesized to be frequent enough to detect a signal of the immediate effect of social media while still minimizing participant burden and hopefully maximizing our ability to retain participation over the entirety of the sampling period.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants.  A priori power analyses were conducted using G*Power (version 3.1.9.2; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to estimate required sample size for fixed effects for hypothesis 2, and projects 228 subjects would be needed to test four predictors (trait social comparison orientation, pre-existing depression, anxiety, and eating disorder symptoms) and three control variables (age, sex, socioeconomic status) at 95% power and an alpha of .05. Given prior studies’ rates of missing and invalid data, it is expected ~75% of data will be usable, thus 300 subjects will be recruited to detect the hypothesized effects.

q14.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants.  A priori power analyses were conducted using G*Power (version 3.1.9.2; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to estimate required sample size for fixed effects for hypothesis 2, and projects 228 subjects would be needed to test four predictors (trait social comparison orientation, pre-existing depression, anxiety, and eating disorder symptoms) and three control variables (age, sex, socioeconomic status) at 95% power and an alpha of .05. Given prior studies’ rates of missing and invalid data, it is expected ~75% of data will be usable, thus 300 subjects will be recruited to detect the hypothesized effects.

question.value:
We will measure the following variables:

Primary outcome variables (measured using EMA, sixteen times a day for 7 days)
1.) Affect (measured on a 0-100 sliding scale)
2.) Jealousy (measured on a 0-100 sliding scale)
3.) Social Comparison (measured on a 0-100 sliding scale)
4.) Instagram Use (measured via yes/no)
5.) Avoidance (measured via yes/no)

Covariates: 
1.) Other Social Media Use (measured via yes/no)
2.) Direct Human Interaction (measured via yes/no)

Moderators:
1.) Demographic Variables (age, sex, SES, education)
2.) Psychopathological Diagnoses (measured via the MINI structured interview, an empirically-validated assessment measures of DSM-V diagnostic criteria)
3.) Anxiety Symptoms (measured via the Penn State Worry Questionnaire)
4.) Depressive Symptoms (measured via the Beck Depression Inventory)
5.) Social Comparison Orientation (measured by the Iowa-Netherlands Comparison Orientation Measure)

Preliminary Analyses: To account for possible time-dependent trends, each individual’s time series data will be detrended by taking the residuals of each variable and regressing it on time. For each individual’s time series, each of the key EMA variables will be lagged by one observation, in order to provide values for time point (t) and the preceding time point (t-1). Lag-1 block-Toeplitz covariance matrices will be generated for each individual. These individual covariance matrices will be averaged to create a group aggregated covariance matrix for nomothetic analyses. Furthermore, before conducting all analyses, variables will be plotted to assess for normality. Prior to the main analyses, the contemporaneous relationships among the variables will be assessed using correlational analyses.

Primary Analyses:
Hypothesis 1: 
Nomothetic models. To assess the lagged hypothesis that increased Instagram use at one time point predicts increased negative affect at the nomothetic level, a lagged vector-autoregressive model will be tested for its fit to the group aggregated covariance matrix, using the structural equation modeling ‘lavaan’ package in R (Roseel, 2012; R Core Team, 2016). To construct this model, all autoregressive paths will be specified (e.g. Instagram use at t-1 predicting Instagram use at t, affect at t -1 predicting affect at t); to specifically test the hypothesized relationships, paths will be specified for Instagram use at t -1 predicting affect at t. In addition, we will specify the path to test the competing directional hypothesis, affect at t -1 predicting Instagram use at t (See Figure 1). Three indices will be used to examine fit: the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) < 0.08, the Comparative Fit Index (CFI) > 0.95, and the Non-normed Fit Index (NNFI) > 0.95. This model will be ran using three different variables; affect, as described above, as well as jealousy and social comparison, both of which will be measured using the same EMA question structure. 

Idiographic models. After testing the hypothesized relationships at the group level, we will test the theoretical model at the individual level. To do this, the raw survey data from each individual dataset will be inputted into R and the lagged vector-autoregressive model described above will be tested for its fit to each individual dataset using separate, person-specific models. As each person will be fit to three models (for affect, jealousy, and social comparison), a total of 900 models will be conducted (as we have 300 participants). As previously noted, a model for a given individual will be determined to be well-fit on the basis of the RMSEA, SRMR, and NFFI; a well-fitting model for a single individual for one variable tested indicates that the structural relationships in that individual’s time series data is structurally consistent with the proposed lagged regression model. Each beta path between the hypothesized relationship paths will be combined into a dataset for moderation analyses.

Hypothesis 2:
Moderation analyses. To assess whether theoretically-relevant group-level characteristics of the sample (measured at baseline) moderate the relationships between Instagram use and affect, jealousy, and social comparison, we will examine whether a number of theoretically important variables (including social comparison orientation, female gender, internalizing disorder diagnoses, self-reported symptoms of depression and anxiety, and level of Instagram and Facebook addiction) interact with Instagram use to predict changes in the three outcome variables assessed in the idiographic models described above (affect, jealousy, social comparison). All models will be run in R.

Hypothesis 3:
Nomothetic models. To examine the contemporaneous correlations between Instagram use and avoidance at the nomothetic level, data from each individual’s time series will be combined into a larger nomothetic dataset. We will run a Pearson correlation between the contemporaneous (Time t) avoidance and contemporaneous (Time t) Instagram use, using the R package ‘Hmics’ (Harrell, 2019).

Idiographic models. After testing the hypothesized correlational relationship at the group level, we will test the model at the individual level. To do this, each individual’s time series data will be inputted into R, and, as described above, we will run Pearson correlations between the contemporaneous (Time t) avoidance and contemporaneous (Time t) Instagram use, using the R package ‘Hmics’ (Harrell, 2019). Individual correlation coefficients will be combined into a dataset for moderation analyses.

Hypothesis 4.
Moderation analyses. To assess whether theoretically-relevant group-level characteristics of the sample (measured at baseline) moderate the strength of the correlation between avoidance and Instagram use, we will examine whether psychopathological variables (including anxiety disorder diagnosis as measured by the M.I.N.I., and symptoms of anxiety as measured by the PSWQ) interact with the correlation coefficient between avoidance and Instagram use. All models will be run in R.

q24.value:
Exploratory Analyses: In addition to the primary analyses outlined above, we plan to also take a data-driven approach to explore the idiosyncrasies in the dynamic structure of each individual’s relationship between using Instagram and affect, jealousy, and social comparison over time. Here, instead of imposing the theoretical lagged models onto each individual’s data set (as described above and seen in Figure 1), we plan to utilize an automatic search procedure using the ‘lavaan’ package in R (Roseel, 2012). The automatic search function uses the Lagrange multiplier test to detect relative change in a model’s chi-squared value (an index of fit) after adding a given parameter. Using this procedure, lavaan iteratively adds parameters that significantly improve fit, one at a time, beginning with the parameter that yields the greatest improvement in model fit. Parameters are no longer added when the Lagrange multiplier tests reveal that there is no benefit to adding another parameter that will improve model fit beyond a user-specified threshold (here, we plan to stop possible paths). The automatic search procedure will be applied to each individuals’ dataset on a person-by-person basis, for each of the three models (for affect, jealousy, and social comparison), yielding 900 individual models.

Furthermore, we plan to take a data-drive approach for both moderation analyses in Aims 2 and 4. While we hypothesize that theoretically-relevant variables measured at baseline will moderate the relationship between Instagram use and the three mental health variables (Aim 1) and the contemporaneous correlation between Instagram use and avoidance (Aim 3), we also plan to run exploratory moderation analyses investigating if demographic variables such as socioeconomic status, age, education, and self-report measurements of emotion regulation, self-esteem, optimism, life satisfaction, and social support each moderate the relationships described above. To correct for multiple comparisons and guard against overfitting, we plan to take a regularized regression approach to running these analyses.

attributes.title: The Impact of Maternal Dydic Interactions on Child Stress Physiology

summary.value:
Exposure to adversity at a young age can alter normative development of one’s stress physiology and impact psychopathology (Bornheimer, Acri, Gopalan, & McKay, 2018; Tottenham & Sheridan, 2010). The HPA system is known for its role in regulating stress (Lupien, Mcewen, Gunnar, & Heim, 2009). Stressful experiences typically lead to an upregulation in the production of cortisol as indicated by regulatory HPA system functioning (Hostinar, Sullivan, & Gunnar, 2014). However, according to the allostatic load model, frequent and prolonged HPA activity may eventually contribute to a dysregulation of the HPA axis (Blair et al., 2008; Propper & Holochwost, 2013). One indicator of a dysregulated profile is when severe stress leads to a downregulation of cortisol, apparent in blunted diurnal slope (Roos, Giuliano, Beauchamp, & Fisher, 2018).
However, parents are capable of providing a protective buffer for their children when present during stress exposure (Bernier, Carlson, & Whipple, 2010; Hackman, Farah, & Meaney, 2010). Yet, how parent-child interactions buffer children from stress remains unclear. The proposed study addresses this gap by investigating the links between dyadic interaction quality, children’s stress physiology and expressed distress following an acute stressor. Baseline data from a larger study completed in the Denver metropolitan area will be used. The data consists of 90 children from families enrolled in the Early Head Start program (EHS) who are at risk for chronic stress exposure. Dyads were randomly placed in an intervention or a control condition.
The objective of this study is to investigate the links between the quality of parent-child interactions, the activation of children’s stress physiology, and how a child’s behavioural displays of distress interacts with parental responses. This study will be completed as part of a requirement for the author’s undergraduate honors thesis.

registration_responses.summary:
Exposure to adversity at a young age can alter normative development of one’s stress physiology and impact psychopathology (Bornheimer, Acri, Gopalan, & McKay, 2018; Tottenham & Sheridan, 2010). The HPA system is known for its role in regulating stress (Lupien, Mcewen, Gunnar, & Heim, 2009). Stressful experiences typically lead to an upregulation in the production of cortisol as indicated by regulatory HPA system functioning (Hostinar, Sullivan, & Gunnar, 2014). However, according to the allostatic load model, frequent and prolonged HPA activity may eventually contribute to a dysregulation of the HPA axis (Blair et al., 2008; Propper & Holochwost, 2013). One indicator of a dysregulated profile is when severe stress leads to a downregulation of cortisol, apparent in blunted diurnal slope (Roos, Giuliano, Beauchamp, & Fisher, 2018).
However, parents are capable of providing a protective buffer for their children when present during stress exposure (Bernier, Carlson, & Whipple, 2010; Hackman, Farah, & Meaney, 2010). Yet, how parent-child interactions buffer children from stress remains unclear. The proposed study addresses this gap by investigating the links between dyadic interaction quality, children’s stress physiology and expressed distress following an acute stressor. Baseline data from a larger study completed in the Denver metropolitan area will be used. The data consists of 90 children from families enrolled in the Early Head Start program (EHS) who are at risk for chronic stress exposure. Dyads were randomly placed in an intervention or a control condition.
The objective of this study is to investigate the links between the quality of parent-child interactions, the activation of children’s stress physiology, and how a child’s behavioural displays of distress interacts with parental responses. This study will be completed as part of a requirement for the author’s undergraduate honors thesis.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Because this study is fully within-subject, we estimate that 300 participants should be sufficient to detect effects similar in size to those observed in previous (but not identical) versions of this study.

analyses.value:
We will predict rated differentiation from whether a brand pair was evaluated by participants before or after the fake news intervention. As above, we predict that the perceived similarity/dissimilarity of brand pairs will be decreased for brands that are evaluated after the fake news intervention.
Our model will predict differentiation (with dissimilar pairs reverse-coded, as specified above) from a contrast code for pre/post treatment, and a continuous variable indicating position from the treatment (e.g. 1 for the first brand pair seen after the treatment, 2 for the second, etc.). This is because the effect of the treatment may wear out over time.

outliers.value: We plan to exclude participants who finish the survey in under two minutes and those who give the same similarity ratings for all brand pairs.

dependent.value: A 1-item measure of perceived differentiation from Extremely different (coded as -5) to Extremely similar (coded as 5; 10-point scale; 12 brand pair replicates). We will transform this variable by multiplying ratings for the dissimilar brands (as determined by pre-test) by -1. This will allow us to predict a negative effect of fake news on ratings across all brand pair replicates without having to introduce an interaction into the model.

conditions.value: This study will be fully within-subjects. Participants will rate the similarity of four, six or eight brand pairs before receiving a fake news salience intervention (an excerpt from a Wikipedia article about fake news). They will then evaluate the similarity of the remaining eight, six or four brand pairs. The display order of these 12 brand pair replicates will be randomized for every participant, as is when the fake news intervention falls (after four, six or eight brand pairs).

hypothesis.value: The main hypothesis is that exposure to the idea of fake news will increase the perceived similarity between brands that are seen as dissimilar at baseline (as determined by two pre-tests), and decrease the perceived similarity between brands that are seen as similar at baseline.

study_type_other.value: We additionally collect two exploratory measures—first a measure of uncertainty tolerance, and second a self-report measure of participants’ pre-study opinions of these brands. We plan to run exploratory analyses including these measures as covariates to test whether they might moderate the effect of fake news on perceived differentiation. Our observed effects may be larger for people who are more intolerant of uncertainty, as fake news should bother them more.

summary.value: The overall goal of current study is to examine normative attitudes in Greek life at Albright College. The current study will inform theory-development and design for future investigations of dissent and group processes in Greek Life at Albright College. Therefore, the primary aim of the current study is to examine “baseline attitudes” that current members of Albright College fraternities and sororities hold toward five group-relevant issues: (1) snap bidding, (2) collaborative leadership, (3) academic excellence, (4) fines, and (5) emphasis on social functions. For each issue, respondents will provide a measure of their personal support for the issue, as well as perceived norms (i.e., how they perceive the rest of the group to feel) about the issue. Please see "2020-01-15 Preregistration.docx" for more information on design, materials, analyses, etc.

attributes.title: Ecological momentary assessment of post-event and anticipatory processing in between two speech tasks: Relationships with anxiety, performance appraisals, and memory

q1.value: Ecological momentary assessment of post-event and anticipatory processing in between two speech tasks: Relationships with anxiety, performance appraisals, and memory

q3.value: The goal of the study is to examine how post-event processing (PEP; Clark & Wells, 1995) following a speech task evolves over time and how it relates to factors important in social anxiety. We will investigate how anxiety levels during, and performance appraisals of, a speech task influence levels of PEP. In turn, we will examine the impact of PEP on levels of anticipatory processing (AP) regarding a second upcoming speech task. In addition, we will examine the influence of PEP on participants’ memory of a speech task and on participants’ performance appraisals.

q4.value:
1.	We hypothesize that PEP will decrease over time, whereas AP will increase over time.

2.	We hypothesize that participants who report more state anxiety will also report more momentary levels of PEP and AP. 

3.	We hypothesize that levels of PEP and AP at one time point will predict subsequent levels of AP, and that levels of PEP will predict subsequent levels of PEP. 

4.	We hypothesize that participants who experience greater peak anxiety during Speech 1 will rate their overall performance on Speech 1 more poorly. Participants who rate their performance more poorly may then engage in more PEP on Day 2 and in turn report more AP on Day 3, which may then contribute to increased anticipatory anxiety before Speech 2.

5.	We hypothesize that higher social anxiety levels will predict greater PEP, which will in turn predict negative change in Speech 1 global performance appraisals.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study uses both a cross-sectional and a repeated measures design. Participants will complete various measures at eight different times points. For example, we will assess symptoms of psychopathology once on the first day of the study, whereas we will assess PEP six times over the course of the next two days.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Given that we are in the process of data collection, we have downloaded datasets related to the study in order to back up the data, to enable research assistants to set up the ecological momentary assessment alerts, and to enable participant compensation. No analyses pertaining to the study hypotheses have been run.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited for this four-day study through the Integrated System of Participation in Research (ISPR) at the University of Ottawa. In addition, participants from the community will be recruited through printed advertisements posted on the University of Ottawa campus and through Facebook. ISPR undergraduate students will be compensated with one course credit on Day 1 and one course credit on Day 4 of the study. Moreover, they will be given the option to enter their name in a draw to win one of four Amazon gift cards each valued at $50 for each EMA alert they complete within 60 minutes of receiving the alert. Community participants will receive the same compensation as ISPR participants, with the exception that they will receive a ticket in the draw for their participation on Days 1 and 4 (instead of ISPR credit).

Day 1
In-person testing will occur at the INSPIRE Laboratory at the University of Ottawa. On Day 1, participants will be told that the purpose of this study is to better understand how people perform during speeches on controversial topics and explore how this is related to their thoughts and feelings. Participants will read the consent form describing the tasks, and potential positive and negative consequences and then indicate their consent (or lack of consent) by signing the document. Then, they will give a rating of their anxiety level using Subjective Units of Distress, after which they will complete a sociodemographic questionnaire and four randomly presented symptom questionnaires using the online survey platform Qualtrics (Qualtrics, 2020). The four questionnaires will be the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales – 21 (DASS-21; Osman et al., 2012), which will assess depressive symptoms within the sample, the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN; Connor et al., 2000), which will measure social anxiety symptom severity, the Post-Event Processing Inventory – Trait Version (PEPI-T; Blackie & Kocovski, 2017), which will assess general tendencies to engage in PEP, and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSES; Rosenberg, 1965), which will assess participants’ self-esteem. 

Participants will give a 5-minute speech on one of two topics (“Discuss the voting rate in Canada and its implications” and “Discuss the cost of university tuition and its implications”), counterbalanced across participants, in front of the research assistant and a video camera that will be filming them. They will have three minutes to prepare this speech without access to pen or paper. Participants will be informed that their speech will be evaluated by the research assistant and that experts on public speaking will view the recording to score and rank them compared to other students. To increase anxiety about the speech task, the research assistant will present the coding sheet that will supposedly be used by the experts to rank their performance on the speech and will tell participants that, following the second speech, they will receive the written feedback from the experts. Participants will be instructed that they can end their speech at any time, but that they must wait in silence until the 5 minutes is up. Right before the speech, participants will provide a second SUDS rating. Participants will give their speech and the experimenter will take note of speech duration. 

Following the speech, participants will provide a third SUDS rating and rate their performance using the Modified Perception of Speech Performance (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011). Participants will then take a 5-minute break, which will let time pass before the assessment of their memory of the speech. They will then complete the Speech-Related Memory Experiences Questionnaire (SR-MEQ; modified from Luchetti & Sutin, 2016), which will assess the phenomenological qualities of participants’ memory for Speech 1. The experimenter will then explain the EMA procedure to participants (see Days 2 and 3). The experimenter will also take note of the 9-hour period during which participants are open to receiving alerts (e.g., from 9am to 6 pm or 12pm to 9pm). Participants will also complete a sample text message alert with the experimenter to ensure that the system works correctly and to answer any questions the participants may have. Lastly, participants will be reminded that they will have a second laboratory session on Day 4 where they will give another recorded speech.

Days 2 and 3
The following EMA procedure is adapted from Connolly and Alloy (2018). On each of the two days following the first laboratory session, participants will receive three text message alerts (for a total of six alerts) from the online reminder service OhDontForget.com. Alerts will be sent at pseudo-random times during the selected 9-hour period, with the constraint that a minimum of 90 minutes occur between each alert and that one alert occur during the first, middle, and last 3 hours of the 9-hour period. The alerts will contain a link to a Qualtrics survey. Participants will be asked to complete the survey within 60 minutes of receiving the alert. The survey will contain items assessing affect, PEP, and AP. 

Day 4
Participants will return to the laboratory on Day 4 and will first give a baseline SUDS rating and rate their performance on Speech 1 once again. They will then complete the SR-MEQ using Qualtrics and provide a second SUDS rating. They will prepare and give a second 5-minute speech on the second counterbalanced topic described above, using the same procedure as for Speech 1. Following the speech, participants will provide a third SUDS rating and rate their performance. Participants will then be debriefed. At this time, participants will be informed of the entirety of the research goals and hypotheses. Additionally, participants will be provided with contact information for the primary researchers in case they have any questions about the experiment. They will also be provided with contact information for the ethics office in case they have any concerns about the research protocol. Finally, in the course of completing the study, participants may become aware of difficulties they are experiencing with anxiety and/or depression. As such, all participants will be provided with a list of self-help resources and mental health practitioners in the area.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 90 participants.

q15.value: Given that data from Day 4 of data collection is crucial to most analyses, data collection will continue until we have reached the desired sample size of 90 participants who have completed Days 1 and 4. Participants who do not complete Day 4 of the study will be excluded from the analyses requiring Day 4 data.

question.value:
The main variables related to the hypotheses as outlined above are as follows:
We will record state anxiety levels using Subjective Units of Distress. We will assess performance appraisals using the Global subscale of the Modified Perception of Speech Performance (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011). We will assess social anxiety severity using the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN; Connor et al., 2000). We will assess memory of the speech using a modified version of the Memory Experiences Questionnaire (MEQ; Luchetti & Sutin, 2016), which we call the Speech-Related Memory Experiences Questionnaire (SR-MEQ). We will assess PEP and AP using items created for the EMA portion of the study. Both the PEP and AP subscales will be composed of 3 positively- and 3 negatively worded items.

For the self-report questionnaires, items will be summed or averaged according to recommendations from the development articles of each questionnaire. Change scores for Speech 1 global performance appraisals will also be computed (i.e., participant’s appraisal of their performance on Day 4 minus on Day 1). For the EMA portion of the study, PEP and AP indices for each time point will be computed by averaging the scores on the three “negative” PEP and AP items, respectively. For the moderation and mediation analyses, the PEP score will consist of the average of the first three PEP EMA ratings (i.e., those on Day 2) and the AP score will consist of the average of the last three AP EMA ratings (i.e., those on Day 3).

HLM will be used to analyze hypotheses 1 to 3. The EMA data, used to test Hypotheses 1 to 3, represent a two-level hierarchy with time points nested within participants, and with all variables of interest at Level 1. We will use the software HLM8 by Raudenbush, Bryk, Cheong, and Congdon (2019). In all HLM analyses, group mean centering will be used. 

When analyzing changes in PEP or AP over time (Hypothesis 1), “time” will be entered as the independent variable, and PEP or AP will be entered as the dependent variable in two separate HLM models. The exact spacing between time points will be represented when assigning values to the “time” variable. This HLM analysis will be linear, but we will also descriptively examine the possibility of non-linear trends by graphing “time” against PEP and against AP.

When analyzing the relationship of anxiety with PEP and AP at a given time (Hypothesis 2), two separate HLM models will be run with state anxiety as the independent variable, and either PEP or AP as the dependent variable. The slopes of these regressions will then be standardized to arrive at approximate correlations to give the reader a sense of the magnitude of each relationship.

When analyzing the effect of PEP on subsequent PEP, PEP on subsequent AP, or AP on subsequent PEP (Hypothesis 3), the data will be structured to permit time-lagged analyses, such that the score on the independent variable at time t will be placed on the same line as the score on the dependent variable at time t+1 for the same participant.

To test hypothesis 4, we plan on conducting a serial mediation analysis (10,000 bootstrap samples, bias corrected). Specifically, we will enter Speech 1 peak anxiety as the independent variable and Speech 2 anticipatory anxiety as the outcome variable. We will then enter Speech 1 global performance appraisals, PEP, and AP as the three mediators in this order.

To test hypothesis 5, we plan on conducting a mediation analysis (10,000 bootstrap samples, bias corrected). We will enter SPIN scores as the independent variable and the Speech 1 global performance appraisals change score as the outcome variable. We will also enter the PEP score as the mediator.

Note: Given the complex nature of the data, it is possible that different analytical techniques or different statistical software will be used (e.g., depending on degree of missing data); that said, all hypotheses will remain the same.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria to determine significant effects, as well as 95% confidence intervals when appropriate. Appropriate effect size estimations will be included when available.

q22.value: Participants who indicate understanding less than 50% of English on the sociodemographic questionnaire and those who were unable to follow experimenter instructions during the testing sessions will be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: As noted above participants who do not participate in Day 4 of the study will be automatically excluded from analyses using Day 4 data (pairwise deletion). Moreover, if the participant does not have any EMA data, they will be excluded from analyses. Remaining partially missing data will be replaced using methods that are appropriate for the amount of missing data present.

q24.value: We expect that PEP will moderate changes in the phenomenological memory qualities of Speech 1 (i.e., Vividness, Coherence, Accessibility, Sensory Details, Visual Perspective, Emotional Intensity, and Valence). Therefore, we will look for interactional effects between time and PEP on the various subscales of the SR-MEQ using repeated-measure moderation analyses for each of the memory qualities.

To increase anxiety about the speech task, the research assistant will present the coding sheet that will supposedly be used by the experts to rank their performance on the speech and will tell participants that, following the second speech, they will receive the written feedback from the experts. Participants will be instructed that they can end their speech at any time, but that they must wait in silence until the 5 minutes is up. Right before the speech, participants will provide a second SUDS rating. Participants will give their speech and the experimenter will take note of speech duration. 

Following the speech, participants will provide a third SUDS rating and rate their performance using the Modified Perception of Speech Performance (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011). Participants will then take a 5-minute break, which will let time pass before the assessment of their memory of the speech. They will then complete the Speech-Related Memory Experiences Questionnaire (SR-MEQ; modified from Luchetti & Sutin, 2016), which will assess the phenomenological qualities of participants’ memory for Speech 1. The experimenter will then explain the EMA procedure to participants (see Days 2 and 3). The experimenter will also take note of the 9-hour period during which participants are open to receiving alerts (e.g., from 9am to 6 pm or 12pm to 9pm). Participants will also complete a sample text message alert with the experimenter to ensure that the system works correctly and to answer any questions the participants may have. Lastly, participants will be reminded that they will have a second laboratory session on Day 4 where they will give another recorded speech.

Days 2 and 3
The following EMA procedure is adapted from Connolly and Alloy (2018). On each of the two days following the first laboratory session, participants will receive three text message alerts (for a total of six alerts) from the online reminder service OhDontForget.com. Alerts will be sent at pseudo-random times during the selected 9-hour period, with the constraint that a minimum of 90 minutes occur between each alert and that one alert occur during the first, middle, and last 3 hours of the 9-hour period. The alerts will contain a link to a Qualtrics survey. Participants will be asked to complete the survey within 60 minutes of receiving the alert. The survey will contain items assessing affect, PEP, and AP. 

Day 4
Participants will return to the laboratory on Day 4 and will first give a baseline SUDS rating and rate their performance on Speech 1 once again. They will then complete the SR-MEQ using Qualtrics and provide a second SUDS rating. They will prepare and give a second 5-minute speech on the second counterbalanced topic described above, using the same procedure as for Speech 1. Following the speech, participants will provide a third SUDS rating and rate their performance. Participants will then be debriefed. At this time, participants will be informed of the entirety of the research goals and hypotheses. Additionally, participants will be provided with contact information for the primary researchers in case they have any questions about the experiment. They will also be provided with contact information for the ethics office in case they have any concerns about the research protocol. Finally, in the course of completing the study, participants may become aware of difficulties they are experiencing with anxiety and/or depression. As such, all participants will be provided with a list of self-help resources and mental health practitioners in the area.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The main variables related to the hypotheses as outlined above are as follows:
We will record state anxiety levels using Subjective Units of Distress. We will assess performance appraisals using the Global subscale of the Modified Perception of Speech Performance (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011). We will assess social anxiety severity using the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN; Connor et al., 2000). We will assess memory of the speech using a modified version of the Memory Experiences Questionnaire (MEQ; Luchetti & Sutin, 2016), which we call the Speech-Related Memory Experiences Questionnaire (SR-MEQ). We will assess PEP and AP using items created for the EMA portion of the study. Both the PEP and AP subscales will be composed of 3 positively- and 3 negatively worded items.
registration_responses.q18.question: For the self-report questionnaires, items will be summed or averaged according to recommendations from the development articles of each questionnaire. Change scores for Speech 1 global performance appraisals will also be computed (i.e., participant’s appraisal of their performance on Day 4 minus on Day 1). For the EMA portion of the study, PEP and AP indices for each time point will be computed by averaging the scores on the three “negative” PEP and AP items, respectively. For the moderation and mediation analyses, the PEP score will consist of the average of the first three PEP EMA ratings (i.e., those on Day 2) and the AP score will consist of the average of the last three AP EMA ratings (i.e., those on Day 3).
registration_responses.q19.question:
HLM will be used to analyze hypotheses 1 to 3. The EMA data, used to test Hypotheses 1 to 3, represent a two-level hierarchy with time points nested within participants, and with all variables of interest at Level 1. We will use the software HLM8 by Raudenbush, Bryk, Cheong, and Congdon (2019). In all HLM analyses, group mean centering will be used. 

When analyzing changes in PEP or AP over time (Hypothesis 1), “time” will be entered as the independent variable, and PEP or AP will be entered as the dependent variable in two separate HLM models. The exact spacing between time points will be represented when assigning values to the “time” variable. This HLM analysis will be linear, but we will also descriptively examine the possibility of non-linear trends by graphing “time” against PEP and against AP.

When analyzing the relationship of anxiety with PEP and AP at a given time (Hypothesis 2), two separate HLM models will be run with state anxiety as the independent variable, and either PEP or AP as the dependent variable. The slopes of these regressions will then be standardized to arrive at approximate correlations to give the reader a sense of the magnitude of each relationship.

When analyzing the effect of PEP on subsequent PEP, PEP on subsequent AP, or AP on subsequent PEP (Hypothesis 3), the data will be structured to permit time-lagged analyses, such that the score on the independent variable at time t will be placed on the same line as the score on the dependent variable at time t+1 for the same participant.

To test hypothesis 4, we plan on conducting a serial mediation analysis (10,000 bootstrap samples, bias corrected). Specifically, we will enter Speech 1 peak anxiety as the independent variable and Speech 2 anticipatory anxiety as the outcome variable. We will then enter Speech 1 global performance appraisals, PEP, and AP as the three mediators in this order.

To test hypothesis 5, we plan on conducting a mediation analysis (10,000 bootstrap samples, bias corrected). We will enter SPIN scores as the independent variable and the Speech 1 global performance appraisals change score as the outcome variable. We will also enter the PEP score as the mediator.

Note: Given the complex nature of the data, it is possible that different analytical techniques or different statistical software will be used (e.g., depending on degree of missing data); that said, all hypotheses will remain the same.

attributes.title: The Social Effects of Cash Transfer Programs

q1.value: The Social Effects of Cash Transfer Programs

q5.value: The authors would like to acknowledge the comments of Professors Rebecca Weitz-Shapiro and Andrew Foster at Brown University for the comments of the survey experiment design., The authors would also like to thank Dr. Nasir Iqbal at the Pakistan Institute of Development Economics (PIDE) for his support in implementing the survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The objective of this study is to understand the social effects of one the largest poverty targeted unconditional cash transfer program in the world: the Benazir Income Support Programme (BISP) in Pakistan. We use data from an original field survey with 1200 households (both its beneficiaries and the non-beneficiaries who narrowly missed program eligibility) where the pre-identified women and their husbands, or available adult male, are interviewed (approximately 2400 respondents). Our study examines the social impacts of poverty targeted cash transfer programs along two critical dimensions: (i) attitudinal shifts, in particular towards redistribution, government, and self-determination, and (ii) behavioural shifts, in the way people access financial networks and develop new social ties with other members of their community.

q16.value: 1) UCT beneficiaries are more in favor of public goods than non-beneficiaries. 2) Women are more likely to prefer public goods in comparison to men. 3) UCT Beneficiaries who are prompted with positive information about government will choose public goods over private goods. When non-beneficiaries receive negative information on public goods, they will choose private goods over public goods. Beneficiaries prompted with negative information about government, or non-beneficiaries who are prompted with positive information about government, should yield ambiguous results. 4) UCT Beneficiaries have higher preferences for redistribution. 5) Beneficiaries give more importance to hard work than luck. 6) Beneficiaries are more likely to access new financial networks. 7) Beneficiaries are more likely to access new social networks. 8) Beneficiaries adopt more altruistic practices than non-beneficiaries.

q17.value: The survey experiment exploits the regression discontinuity design (RDD) to make causal inferences, as the sample includes individuals that are beneficiaries (treatment), and nearly eligible non-beneficiaries (control) with PMT scores close to BISP’s program's cutoff score of 16.17. We embed a survey experiment in the RDD sample, with two different priming prompts and a control prompt. The three versions of the prompt are randomized across respondents (each of the three prompts will be assigned to one third of the sample, making sure that 50% of the respondents for each version is a BISP beneficiary and the remaining 50% is not a beneficiary of the program).

q19.value: A random sample of 1200 respondents (600 respondents assigned to control and 600 respondents assigned to treatment)

q27.value: Researchers, Dr. Nasir Iqbal, Pakistan Institute of Development Economics (PIDE)

attributes.title: Measuring the psychological drivers of participation in collective action to address violence against women in Mumbai, India
attributes.description: A growing number of public health interventions involve community members in activism to prevent violence against women (VAW), but the psychological drivers of participation are poorly understood. In this project, we developed a new scale for measuring three proposed drivers of participation in collective action to address VAW in the context of urban informal settlements in Mumbai, India: perceived legitimacy, perceived efficacy, and collective action norms. Using a household survey of over 2,500 men and women, we examined its item, construct, and criterion validity. A valid scale would provide useful insight into modifiable beliefs and attitudes that community mobilisation interventions can address to inspire activism in low-resource contexts.

summary.value: This project contains cleaned data, a codebook and supplementary analytical tables for a project to develop a new scale for measuring possible psychological drivers of participation in collective action to address violence against women in the context of urban informal settlements in Mumbai, India.

registration_responses.summary: This project contains cleaned data, a codebook and supplementary analytical tables for a project to develop a new scale for measuring possible psychological drivers of participation in collective action to address violence against women in the context of urban informal settlements in Mumbai, India.
